perturbation.original_text: If Company fails to cure the identified breach within thirty (30) days after the date of the notice, Investor may terminate this IP Agreement by written notice to Company.
perturbation.changed_text: If Company fails to cure the identified breach within ten (10) days after the date of the notice, Investor may terminate this IP Agreement by written notice to Company.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the cure period to ten (10) days may be considered unreasonably short, particularly in complex commercial agreements involving intellectual property rights. Standard commercial practice often allows for a 30-day cure period, and some jurisdictions may view a shorter period as a violation of good faith and fair dealing, making the termination clause potentially unenforceable.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Breach of Good Faith and Fair Dealing (Varies by state, but often implied in contracts under common law)

perturbation.original_text: If Investor fails to cure the identified breach within thirty (30) days after the date of the notice, Company may terminate this IP Agreement by written notice to Investor.
perturbation.changed_text: If Investor fails to cure the identified breach within five (5) days after the date of the notice, Company may terminate this IP Agreement by written notice to Investor.
perturbation.explanation: Similar to the first change, reducing the cure period for the Investor to five (5) days creates an unreasonably short timeframe, potentially violating the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing. This is especially problematic as Synchron, a California corporation, is listed as a principal in the IP agreement.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Breach of Good Faith and Fair Dealing (Varies by state, but often implied in contracts under common law, particularly relevant under California law)

perturbation.original_text: The Parties shall first attempt in good faith to resolve any Dispute by negotiation and consultation between themselves, including without limitation not fewer than two (2) negotiation sessions which shall occur within ten (10) Business Days of the Dispute Notice. In the event that such dispute is not resolved on an informal basis by the conclusion of the second negotiation session, or, if either Party has not participated in negotiation sessions as to which notice has been given (the last day of such time period, the "Escalation to Mediation Date"), either Party may initiate mediation under Article 18.02.
perturbation.changed_text: The Parties shall first attempt in good faith to resolve any Dispute by negotiation and consultation between themselves, including without limitation not fewer than two (2) negotiation sessions which shall occur within two (2) Business Days of the Dispute Notice. In the event that such dispute is not resolved on an informal basis by the conclusion of the second negotiation session, or, if either Party has not participated in negotiation sessions as to which notice has been given (the last day of such time period, the "Escalation to Mediation Date"), either Party may initiate mediation under Article 18.02.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the initial negotiation period to two (2) business days might be considered insufficient, especially for complex IP disputes. Courts might view this as an unreasonable restriction on the opportunity to resolve disputes amicably, potentially undermining the enforceability of the dispute resolution clause. While there is no strict law that prevents this, a very short negotiation window could indicate lack of good faith attempt to resolve conflict.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Implied Covenant of Good Faith and Fair Dealing (Related to Dispute Resolution)
